item.title: How I created the React-domproperty
item.description: It was several days ago when I had the idea to create a library that simply convert DOM attributes into React-style attributes . Thisâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
It was several days ago when I had the idea to create a library that simply convert DOM attributes into React-style attributes. This tool works as a dependency for my another tool React-gensvg that generates tsx/jsx files from SVG files.

Difference between DOM and React attributes

In React, all DOM properties and attributes (including event handlers) should be camelCased.

However, the exception is aria-* and data-* attributes. The values of attributes are different at sometimes. The most obvious one is style, which is CSS string in DOM tag other than an Object in React.

Development

At the beginning of this month, I created several fronend boilerplates for different purposes, with which could save me lots of time on configuring. The boilerplate I used for this project is ts-rollup-boilerplate. You could check it out if intrested.

Functionality

This tool is basically convert DOM attributes into camelCased attributes. Furthermore, custom attributes like custom-data should also be bypassed by this tool.

It's not hard to achieve this core functionality, only combining RegExp and string method replace.

// transform attributes to camelCased
const reactlize = (attr)=> attr.replace(/[\-\:]([a-z])/g, val => val[1].toUpperCase());

Probably you're thinking what a silly task. Well, actually it is.

Correctness

How to make sure all DOM properties and attributes, which supported by React, are able to be handeled with this tool?

The solution is through reading react-dom code and GlobalEventHandlers on MDN.

I also use React DOM Elements as a reference.

Additionally, there are several DOM attributes are renamed in React such as class is renamed to className, which need to be handled as a corner case.

Github repo

You could check the source code React-domproperty.

item.title: Scroll Observer
item.description: Detect scroll In my opinion, there are two ways to detect scroll in page. One uses window.addEventListener('scroll', callback) and anotherâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
Detect scroll

In my opinion, there are two ways to detect scroll in page. One uses window.addEventListener('scroll', callback) and another is use Web API Intersection Observer.

The motivation of Intersection Observer

Facbook IIFE

Here is a snippet from Jest website.

/**
 * Copyright (c) 2017-present, Facebook, Inc.
 *
 * This source code is licensed under the MIT license found in the
 * LICENSE file in the root directory of this source tree.
 */

/* eslint-disable */
(function scrollSpy() {
  var OFFSET = 10;
  var timer;
  var headingsCache;

  var findHeadings = function findHeadings() {
    return headingsCache || document.querySelectorAll('.toc-headings > li > a');
  };

  var onScroll = function onScroll() {
    if (timer) {
      // throttle
      return;
    }

    timer = setTimeout(function() {
      timer = null;
      var activeNavFound = false;
      var headings = findHeadings(); // toc nav anchors

      /**
       * On every call, try to find header right after  <-- next header
       * the one whose content is on the current screen <-- highlight this
       */

      for (var i = 0; i < headings.length; i++) {
        // headings[i] is current element
        // if an element is already active, then current element is not active
        // if no element is already active, then current element is active
        var currNavActive = !activeNavFound;
        /**
         * Enter the following check up only when an active nav header is not yet found
         * Then, check the bounding rectangle of the next header
         * The headers that are scrolled passed will have negative bounding rect top
         * So the first one with positive bounding rect top will be the nearest next header
         */

        if (currNavActive && i < headings.length - 1) {
          var heading = headings[i + 1];
          var next = decodeURIComponent(heading.href.split('#')[1]);
          var nextHeader = document.getElementById(next);

          if (nextHeader) {
            var top = nextHeader.getBoundingClientRect().top;
            currNavActive = top > OFFSET;
          } else {
            console.error('Can not find header element', {
              id: next,
              heading: heading,
            });
          }
        }
        /**
         * Stop searching once a first such header is found,
         * this makes sure the highlighted header is the most current one
         */

        if (currNavActive) {
          activeNavFound = true;
          headings[i].classList.add('active');
        } else {
          headings[i].classList.remove('active');
        }
      }
    }, 100);
  };

  document.addEventListener('scroll', onScroll);
  document.addEventListener('resize', onScroll);
  document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
    // Cache the headings once the page has fully loaded.
    headingsCache = findHeadings();
    onScroll();
  });
})();

item.content:encoded:
Problem

Sometimes there isn't a .d.ts file for a imported third-party module, we have to write a type definition file for it. Or you want to overwirte its type definitions.

tsconfig

To use our custom type definition files, it's required to change tsconfig.json to tell compiler where to find them. See Typesciprt issue.

{
    "compilerOptions":{
        // ...
        "baseUrl": "./", // see 
        "paths": {
            "*": ["src/type"]  // a dir where you put your custom type definition file
            },
        "typeRoots": ["./node_modules/@types", "./src/type"],
        // ...
    },
    "exclude": ["node_modules", "src/type/name", ...]
}

add definition files

a default export module

See template file module-plugin.d.ts.

// src/main.ts
import foobar from 'de-foobar'

function foo(){
    console.log(foobar(1));
    console.log(foobar('2'));
}

declare module 'de-foobar' {
    function print(str:string|number):string;
    export default print;
}

a named export module

import {Bar} from 'react-foobar-component';

const foo = '1';
const ABar= ()=>{
    return <Bar foo={foo}><Bar/>
}

declare module 'react-foobar-component'{
    export class Bar extends React.Component<BarProps & any, any> {}
 
    interface BarProps{
        foo?: number|string
    }
}

Question

A(local machine) <-> B(proxy server) <-> C(git repo server)

I would like to git clone the repo on local machine A instead of ssh-agent forwarding that clones the repo on proxy server B. Why not clone the repo directly on A? Well, for the sake of security or the network latencyï¼ˆdownload speed). For Chinese users, this is mainly due to GFW.

Solution

clone with normal ssh url

  1. setup a tunnel between localhost port and proxy server

  1. setup .ssh/config
# .ssh/config
Host github.com
  User git
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/github_id_rsa
  ProxyCommand nc -x localhost:9999 %h %p
  1. git clone
git clone git@github.com:[username]/[reponame].git

Here we only proxy commands to github.com.

clone with localhost ssh url

  1. setup a tunnel between localhost port and proxy server that only forward conections to github.com:22
ssh -NL 9999:github.com:22 [proxy_user]@[proxy_hostname]
  1. git clone

item.title: ffmpeg basic usage
item.description: Common options Check video metadata Transform video type Set Video fps We could adjust the video fps, decreasing the output file fps mostlyâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
Common options

-an # video only
-vn # audio only
-acodec # audio decoder, value copy for copying original audio
-vcodec # video decoder, value copy for copying original video
-f # output type
-bf # B frame
-g # keyframe interval
-s # set height and width
-ss # set start 0:0:01
-t # set duration 0:0:02
-r # set rating
-c:v # set output video type
-c:a # set output audio type
-y # overwrite file has the same name

Check video metadata

ffmpeg -i video.mp4

Transform video type

# transform flv to mp4, etc
ffmpeg -i video.flv video.mp4

Set Video fps

We could adjust the video fps, decreasing the output file fps mostly, when we know the fps.

# set input video fps to adjust its total time length
# video default fps 25
# increas video speed to 2x
# 50fps
ffmpeg -r 50 -i video.mp4 output.mp4
# decrease video speed to 1/5
# 5fps
ffmpeg -r 5 -i video.mp4 output.mp4

# set output video fps to adjust its rating
# e.g input video 60 fps and we only need 30fps
ffmpeg -i video.mp4 -r 30 output.mp4

Video Concatenation

file 01.flv
file 02.flv
file 04.flv
file 05.flv
file 06.flv
file 07.flv

ffmpeg -f file -i file.txt video.mp4

Split video into images

# in default frame rate 25
# image name pattern: images-0001.png
ffmpeg -i video.mp4 images-%04d.png
# set output frame rate
# image name pattern: images-000001.png
ffmpeg -i video.mp4 -r 60 images-%06d.png

The %06d dictates that the ordinal number of each output image will be formed using 6 digits like 000001.

Create thumbnails per X seconds of the video

We could use -vframes option, fps video filter and select video filter to achieve this.

# output a single frame from video at specific time
ffmpeg -i video.mp4 -ss 00:00:01 -vframes 1 image.png
# per second
ffmpeg -i video.mp4 -vf fps=1 image-%06d.png
# per minute
ffmpeg -i video.mp4 -vf fps=1/60 image-%06d.png
# per tem minutes
ffmpeg -i video.mp4 -vf fps=1/600 image-%04.png
# per I-frame
ffmpeg -i video.mp4 -vf "select='eq(pict_type,PICT_TYPE_I)'" -vsync vfr image-%04d.png

Images into video

# simple way using default fps 25fpx
ffmpeg -f image2 -i images/%06d.png -vcodec libx264 output.mp4
# set input images fps using -framerate
# set output fps and bps using -b:v
# e.g 8000kb/s
ffmpeg -f image2 -framerate 30 -i %06.png -b:v 8000k output.mp4

Split the audio out of video and combine

# only video with -vn
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -vn -acodec copy output.m4a
# only audio with -an
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -an -vcodec copy output-video.mp4
# combine
ffmpeg -i video.mp4 -i audio.mp3 -vcoder copy -acodec copy output.mp4

Reverse

# reverse video
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -vf reverse output.mp4
# reverse audio and video
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -vf reverse -af reverse output.mp4

Hardware acceleration

# check hardware acceleration methods
ffmpeg -hwaccels
# check nvidia GPU cuvid
ffmpeg -codecs | grep cuvid

Reference

ffmpeg Official DOC ffmpeg-select-frames-at-position-of-video how-do-i-use-ffmpeg-to-split-a-video-into-images-and-then-reassemble-exactly-the ffmpegå¸¸ç”¨å‘½ä»¤

item.title: Git clone subdirectory
item.description: Problem If you try to use git to clone a huge repository to figure out what's behind the scens, you will get a lot of files in the endâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
Problem

If you try to use git to clone a huge repository to figure out what's behind the scens, you will get a lot of files in the end, which may lead you to the wrong way. To concertrate on the main functionality, we need to filter out the files that we are curioused about.

Use git sparse-checkout

We could use git sparse-checkout that introduced in Git v2.25 to filter out the files we need in current repository. However, it still require to clone the whole repository first. ğŸ¶ What's the difference between opening the subdirectory in a new IDE window and this git sparse-checkout approach?

# no checkout clone
git clone --no-checkout repo-url
cd repo-name
git sparse-checkout init --cone
git sparse-checkout set sub-dir1 sub-dir2

git clone --no-checkout git@github.com:gatsbyjs/gatsby.git
cd gatsby
git sparse-checkout --cone
git sparse-checkout set packages

Use git checkout

Another way is to use git init to create an empty local repository. Then use git remote add to set its remote upstream. We could use git clone and git checkout to checkout subdirectories.

Sounds familiar? It is equivalent to the git sparse-checkout.

git init
git remote add remote-name git-url
git fetch remote-name
git checkout remote-name/branch -- path/to/subdir

git init
git remote add tensorflow https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow.git
git fetch tensorflow
git checkout tensorflow/master -- tools

Use Browser-plugin

For Chrome users, there is a plugin called GitZip. It can make the sub-directories and files that you select on the web page as zip and download it.

function genRGB(r,g,b,a,isHex=false){
    if(isHex){
        let hex = `#${r}${g}${b}`;
        if(a){

/*
hsla(h,s,l,a)
h: [0deg,360deg]
s: [0,1]
l: [0,1]
a: [0,1]
*/
function hsl2rgb(str){
    if(!(/hsla?\(.*\)/).test(str)){
        throw new TypeError('Not a valid hsl format');
    }
    const groups = str.match(/hsla?\((\S+)deg[,\s]*(\d?\.?\d?)[,\s]*(\d?\.\d?)[,\s]*(\d?\.?\d?)?\)/);
    if(!groups[3]){
        throw new TypeError('Not a valid hsl format');
    }
    let h = Number.parseInt(groups[1]),
        s = Number.parseFloat(groups[2]).toFixed(2),
        l = Number.parseFloat(groups[3]).toFixed(2);
        a = groups[4]? Number.parseFloat(groups[4]).toFixed(2): 1;
    const _hsl2rgb = (h,s,l,a)=>{
        const fn = (n)=>{
            const k = (n+h/30)%12;
            const a = s*Math.min(l,1-l);
            return l - a*Math.max(-1,Math.min(k-3,9-k,1));
        }
        return [fn(0)*255,fn(8)*255,fn(4)*255,a*255];
    }
    let [r,g,b,alpha] = _hsl2rgb(h,s,l,a);
    return genRGB(r,g,b,alpha);
}

/**
 * Converts an RGB color value to HSL. Conversion formula
 * adapted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HSL_color_space.
 * Assumes r, g, and b are contained in the set [0, 255] and
 * returns h, s, and l in the set [0, 1].
 *
 * @param   Number  r       The red color value
 * @param   Number  g       The green color value
 * @param   Number  b       The blue color value
 * @return  Array           The HSL representation
 */
function rgbToHsl(r, g, b) {
  r /= 255, g /= 255, b /= 255;

  var max = Math.max(r, g, b), min = Math.min(r, g, b);
  var h, s, l = (max + min) / 2;

  if (max == min) {
    h = s = 0; // achromatic
  } else {
    var d = max - min;
    s = l > 0.5 ? d / (2 - max - min) : d / (max + min);

    switch (max) {
      case r: h = (g - b) / d + (g < b ? 6 : 0); break;
      case g: h = (b - r) / d + 2; break;
      case b: h = (r - g) / d + 4; break;
    }

    h /= 6;
  }

  return [ h, s, l ];
}

TLDR

  • UI design(optional)
  • logical functionality
  • Test and code

Workflow

UI Design

Designing and styling the UI component is the easiest step before adding any functionality. We could use design tool like Sketch or Figma to export the CSS code and modify it a little to fit the layout.

Logical functionality

In most time we need to define the component's interactive behaviors to get a better user experience. For example, add transition animation for toggling a menu.

Test and code

TDD(Test-driven development) is a good choice but I rather like writing test use cases later , which may be considered as a bad habbit.

item.title: Run parallel commands in Yarn/Npm
item.description: TLDR Use & instead of && in unix-like system. Install npm package npm-run-all to run parallel commands in non-unix-like systemâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
TLDR

  • Use & instead of && in unix-like system.
  • Install npm package npm-run-all to run parallel commands in non-unix-like system.
A ; B # Run A and then B, regardless of success of A
A && B # Run B if A succeeded
A || B # Run B if A failed
A & #Run A in background.

Problem

What I was trying to achieve was that running two scripts that both never exited until met errors in one NPM/Yarn command using &&. At first sight, it seemed work but turned out to fail.

I've not been writing bash scripts for a long time. In fact, the && in unix-like system bash scripts means run command in turn that only the previous command successsfully exit then it runs the next command. However, the first command works like a file watcher using chokidar and the second command has to wait the first command to exit so it can't work.

Solution

Now that && doesn't work, we need to find a way to run commands concurrently. It could be achieved by plugins in non-unix like system. In unix like system, changing && to & works.

a & b starts a first, moves it to background and starts b. The drawback is that the background process couldn't be exited through ctrl-c/ctrl-z.

item.title: webpack inject absolute paths for routing issues
item.description: Problem I'm using React-router-dom for frontend routing which works well when visiting root paths like localhost:port/root but failsâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
Problem

I'm using React-router-dom for frontend routing which works well when visiting root paths like localhost:port/root but fails when trying to visit non-root paths like localhost:port/root/sub. As a result, the webpack dev server would send a 404 status error.

Solution

Opening the console in browser's dev tool, I found that there was one more error that localhost:port/root/sub/bundle.js couldn't be loaded as it was an invalid MIME type. However, in fact the output bundle file is under output directory's root. The correct path for script' src should be /bundle.js instead of a relative path bundle.js that made the browser trying to request the non-existed file from the server.

This problem in my situation was due to the webpack missing correct configuration on how to output the bundle files.

// in webpack.config.js
...
output:{
  // set publicPath to '/' so that html-webpack-plugin could inject bundle file using absoulte path
  // more details on https://webpack.js.org/configuration/output/#outputpublicpath
  publicPath:'/'.
  ...
}
...
devServer:{
  ...
  // use html5 history API in react-router-dom
  historyApiFallback: true,
  ...
}

Reference

Answers from react-router-urls-dont-work-when-refreshing-or-writing-manually helpful with this problem especially the accepted give a great explaination.

item.title: Techniques learnt from exercises
item.description: About this post This is a summary post about algorithm exercises. The solutions may written in C++ or javaScript. Common approach for mostâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
About this post

This is a summary post about algorithm exercises. The solutions may written in C++ or javaScript.

Common approach for most problems

We couold first consider simpler situation or some special cases that easy to be solved. Like 3blue1brown said in his video The hardest problem on the hardest test, you could first consider the 2D version problem and then use similiar idea in the higher 3D problem. Feynman also said smiliar idea.

Hmm, it sounds like divide and conquer or dynamic-programming. The truth is both of them divide the original problem into smaller subproblems and we need to merge solutions of subproblems to get the answer we want.

For example, to solve the 321. Create Maximum Number, you have to consider simple situations first.

var maxNumber = function(nums1, nums2, k) {
    /*
    Intuition:
    First consider simpler situation.
    1. If we only use one of arrays, what we would get.
    We could choose min(nums1.length,k) at most.
    We could drop nums1.length - min(nums1.length,k) at most.

    2. If we only use two of arrays, what we would get.
    We could choose i numbers in nums1 and choose j numbers in nums2.
    Hence, i = min(nums1.length-k,0) and i <= min(nums1.length,k)
    j = k-i

    we could simplifiy the question to above simple subproblem and merge the result to get the answer.
    
    */
    const m = nums1.length;
    const n = nums2.length;
    let ans = new Array(k).fill(0);
    let i = 0, j = 0,count = 0;
    const merge = (a,b)=>{
        let ans = [];
        while(a.length + b.length > 0){
            if(a>b){
               ans.push(a.shift());
            }else{
               ans.push(b.shift());
            }
        }
        return ans;
    }
    const getMaxArray = (arr,k)=>{
       const n = arr.length;
       let could_drop = n - k;
       let ans = []; 
       for(let num of arr){
        while(could_drop>0&&ans.length>0&&ans[ans.length-1]<num){
            // smaller then reset
            ans.pop();
            could_drop--;
        }
         ans.push(num);
       }
       while(ans.length>k){
           ans.pop();
       }
       return ans;
    }
    for(let i = Math.max(k-n,0);i<=Math.min(k,m);i++){
        let candidate = merge(getMaxArray(nums1,i),getMaxArray(nums2,k-i));   
        if(candidate>ans){
           ans = candidate; 
        }
    }
    return ans;
};

The question 310. Minimum Height Trees could also be solved using this strategy.

var findMinHeightTrees = function(n, edges) {
   /*
  Brute force:
   Choose each node as root and use BFS to traversal the tree for the minimum height
   
  Intuition:
   Consider a simpler graph - path graph, the root of MHT is the middlest node of the tree.
   We could use two pointers to find such nodes.
   
   Now consider a tree. We could use multiple pointers that start from the leaves at the same speed and remove these leaves until there are 1 or 2 nodes left. Simliar to graph topologicalsort but we start from the leaves that out degree is 0.
   
   For a tree that has n nodes,there are always n-1 edges.
   */ 
    if(n==1){
        return [0];
    }
    let neighbors = new Array(n);
    for(let i = 0;i<n;i++){
        neighbors[i] = new Set();
    }
    for(let edge of edges){
        neighbors[edge[0]].add(edge[1]);
        neighbors[edge[1]].add(edge[0]);
    }
    let leaves = [];
    for(let i =0;i<n;i++){
        if(neighbors[i].size==1){
            leaves.push(i);           
         }
    }
    while(n>2){
       n -= leaves.length; 
       let next_level = [];
       for(let idx of leaves){
          let neighbor = neighbors[idx].values().next().value;
          neighbors[neighbor].delete(idx); 
          if(neighbors[neighbor].size==1){
             next_level.push(neighbor); 
          }
       }
        leaves = next_level;
    }
    return leaves;
};

Define lines for graph

Sometimes you could define line to simplify the question. Go and check 335. Self Crossing

var isSelfCrossing = function(x) {
    /*
    Intuition:
    Consider only line crosses itself
    
    Define lines:
    
    case 1
       b
    x------x
    |      | 
    |    a |   f
 c  |      |  --x
    |      x    |
    |           | e
    x-----------x
          d
          
  1. f >= b - d
  2. a >= c - e
          
    case 2
       b
    x------x
  c |      | 
    |  d   | a  
    x---   | 
           x   
  1. d >= b 
  2. a >= c 
    */
    let b=0,c=0,d=0,e=0,f=0;
    for(let a of x){
        if (d >= b && b > 0 && (a >= c || ((c - e) <= a && c >= e && (d - f) <= b)))
          {
            return true;
            }
        f = e; e = d; d = c; c = b; b = a;
    }
   return false; 
};

With the help of mathematics

It may be complicated as someone said but at least the first time I saw 343. Integer Break I calculated its derivative to get the maximum. And then we could use it to get O(1) solution. 

var integerBreak = function(n) {
    /*
    Intuition:
    a + b >= 2*sqrt(a*b)
    <=> x1 + x2 + ... + xn >= n*(x1*...*xn)^(1/n)
    when x1 = x2 = ... = xn, the equal is satisfised.
    
    For the question, we need to break the sum into suitable number of parts to get the answer but how.
    
    If n is divide by x, there are n/x x's which gives us the product x^(n/x).
    
    f(x) = x^(n/x) => f'(x) = (1-lnx)*n*x^(n/x - 2)
    0 < x < e: f'(x)>0
    x = e: f'(x) = 0
    x > e: f'(x)< 0
    
    The closest integer to e is 3. 
    */
    if(n<2){
        return -1;
    }
    if(n==2)return 1;
    if(n==3)return 2;
    let n3 = Math.floor(n/3);
    let remainder = n%3;
    if(remainder==1){
       remainder = 4; 
        n3--;
    }else if(remainder==0){
       remainder = 1; 
    }
    return (3**n3) * remainder;
};

Imitate recursive approach with stack

In most of time I choose stack instead of recursive approach is due to the time complexity requirement. Otherwise, you would get TLE on OJ.

Many binary tree serializatin string verifying problems could be solved use stack e.g 331. Verify Preorder Serialization of a Binary Tree.

var isValidSerialization = function(preorder) {
    /*
    Intuition:
    Use the stack to imitate recursive approach (dfs).
    
    1. If meet non-null node, we continue recursive calling and push it to stack.
    2. If meet null node, we return to above recursive calling and check the stack top.
    If stack top is also a null node, pop two nodes that one for left and one for parent each turn until top isn't a null node. If the stack is empty in poping process, then it's invalid.
    If not, push it to stack and continue.
    
    If the serialization string is correct, then there are only one null node in the stack.
    Otherwise it's not correct.
    */
    let stack = [];
    let nodes = preorder.split(',');
    for(let node of nodes){
       if(node=='#'&&stack.length>0&&stack[stack.length-1]=='#'){
            while(stack.length>0&&stack[stack.length-1]=='#') {
               stack.pop(); 
               if(stack.length==0){
                   return false;
               }
                stack.pop();
            }   
       } 
      stack.push(node);  
    }
    return stack.length == 1&&stack[0]=='#';
};

Relationship between tree and graph

331. Verify Preorder Serialization of a Binary Tree. could also be solved with the degree in graph.

var isValidSerialization = function(preorder) {
    /*
    Intuition:
    1. In pre-order traversal, first visit the node, then traverse on left subtree, finally traverse on right subtree.
    2. As there are always symbols for null nodes, the non-nodes in string must have left child and right child.
    3. One non-null node produces 2 edges and consumes 1 edge which increase edge by 1 in total.
       And one null node produces 0 edges and consumes 1 edge which decrease edge by 1 in total.
       Each time we meet a node, we derease the edges by 1 as it consumes one edge.
       If it's not null, then we increase 2 edges.
       If it's null, we repeat the process.
       
       If the serialization string is correct, the final edge number is 0 as there no more redundant edges. 
       Otherwise it's not correct.
    */
    let nodes = preorder.split(',');
    let edges = 1;
    for(let node of nodes){
       edges -= 1;
       if(edges<0){
           return false;
       }
       if(node!='#'){
           edges += 2;
       }
    }
    return edges == 0;
};

use bit to store simple state

In most languages, integer are defined using two's complement for representation and float point number uses IEEE-754 standard.

The most common use for bit is to represent states so we could use it to reduce both time and space complexity. For example, the question Maximum Product of Word Lengths. 

var maxProduct = function(words) {
    /*
    Intuition:
    To get the maximum value of two words with no common letters, we need to filter such no common letter words for each word.
    To improve efficiency, we could use bit to store state of each letter for a word instaed of HashMap.
    */
    words = words.map(word=>{
        let memoBit = 0;
        for(let i = 0;i<word.length;i++){
            memoBit |= (1<<(word.charCodeAt(i)-97));
        }
        return [memoBit,word.length];
    })
    let ans = 0;
    for(let i = 0;i<words.length-1;i++){
        for(let j = i+1;j<words.length;j++){
            if((words[i][0]&words[j][0])==0){
                ans = Math.max(words[i][1]*words[j][1],ans);
            }
        }
    }
    return ans;
};

Iterator Cache

We could use two variable to cache iterator for peeking. Here is the related problem Cached peeking iterator. That Google's java library grava also use similiar approach.

Skip operations

In some problems we are asked to do some operations on the input in order to calculate sort of optimal value. Ironically, we could skip such operations. Please check the problem 241. Different Ways to Add Parentheses which I did add parentheses to input at first. 

var mem = new Map();
var ops = ['*','-','+'];

var diffWaysToCompute = function(input) {
    /*
    We could use divide and conquer here.
    But at first we must have this idea that adding parentheses equals to deciding which part compute first.
    Moreover, the question require the computed results instead of expressions so we do not need to add parentheses actually and we just split the input into two parts: left and right.
    Now it's obvious that we could use divide and conquer here to repeat the above process until reaching the
    simplest subproblem.
    */
    if(mem.has(input)){
        return mem.get(input);
    }
    let ans = [];    
    for(let i = 0;i<input.length;i++){
        if(ops.includes(input[i])){
            let left =  input.slice(0,i); 
            let right = input.substring(i+1);
            let left_ans = diffWaysToCompute(left);
            let right_ans= diffWaysToCompute(right);
            for(let a of left_ans){
                for(let b of right_ans){
                    switch(input[i]){
                        case '+':
                            ans.push(a+b);
                            break;
                        case '-':
                            ans.push(a-b);
                            break;
                        case '*':
                            ans.push(a*b);
                            break;
                    }
                }
            }
        }
    }
    if(ans.length==0){
        // the simplest subproblem
        ans.push(Number.parseInt(input));
    }
    mem.set(input,ans);
    return ans;
};

Bit count

Here comes the Brian Kernighan's algorithm. It could be used to count set bit in a number. The key operation is x&=(x-1) that would remove the last set bit.

Here is a problem 201. Bitwise AND of Numbers Range could solved using this trick.

var rangeBitwiseAnd = function(m, n) {
    while(n>m){
        n &= (n-1);
    }
    return n;
};
// or
var rangeBitwiseAnd = function(m, n) {
    let right_common = 0;
    while(m!=n){
        m>>=1;
        n>>=1;
        right_common++;
    }
    return m<<right_common;
};

And it could also be used to solve problem 260. Single Number III.

var singleNumber = function(nums) {
    /*
    Intuition:
        a XOR a = 0
        a XOR 0 = a
        
        Assume the two distinct element in array are x and y.
        If we XOR all elements, then the result would be x XOR y.
        As x and y are distinct, there must be at least one set bit in the result.
        Here we could use the rightmost set bit in the result to divide the array into two parts.
        One with this set bit and another with this bit unset. In this way x and y would fall into different group.
        
        Then we could XOR all numbers in each group to get x and y directly.
        
        
    */
    let x_y = 0;
    for(let i = 0;i<nums.length;i++){
       x_y ^= nums[i]; 
    }
    const getLowBit = x => x&(-x);
    const checkBit = (bit,x)=>{
       if((x&bit)==bit){
           return true;
       } else{
           return false;
       }
    }
    let bit = getLowBit(x_y);
    let x = 0, y = 0;
    for(let i = 0;i<nums.length;i++){
        if(checkBit(bit,nums[i])){
            x ^= nums[i];
        }else{
            y ^= nums[i];
        }
    }
    return [x,y];
};

Binary Indexed Tree

Binary indexed tree is a great data structure for range sum problem.

Range Sum Query - Mutable is a good practise for implementing this data structure.

class NumArray {
private:
    class BinaryIndexedTree{
        private:
            /*
            Assume vals[y] is parent node of child node vals[x], we have
             (1) y = x - (x & (-x))
             (2) vals[x] = sum of arr[y...x)
            */
            vector<int> vals; 
            int _size;
            static inline int getLowBit(int i){
                return i & (-i);
            }
        public:
            BinaryIndexedTree(int size): _size(size), vals(size+1,0){}
        
            void update(int i,int val){
                i = i + 1;
                while(i<=_size){
                   vals[i] += val; 
                   i += getLowBit(i);
                }
            }
        
            // sum of [0...i]
            int getSum(int i){
                int sum = 0;
                i = i + 1;
                while(i>0){
                   sum += vals[i];  
                   i -= getLowBit(i);
                }
                return sum;
            }
    };
    BinaryIndexedTree tree;
    vector<int> vals;
public:
    NumArray(vector<int>& nums):tree(nums.size()),vals(nums){
        for(int i = 0;i<nums.size();i++){
           tree.update(i,nums[i]); 
        }
    }
    
    void update(int i, int val) {
       tree.update(i,val-vals[i]); 
       vals[i] = val;
    }
    
    int sumRange(int i, int j) {
       return tree.getSum(j)-tree.getSum(i-1);
    }
};

End of post

Solving algorithm problems is time consuming and it's not as fun as developing but it worth time practising some often used algorithms and data structures.

Note

  1. enable SMB in Windows functions.
  2. make sure both machine with MacOS and machine with Windows connect to the same local network. (Do not enable SMB in public network!)
  3. Change firewall settings in Windows otherwise you could not connect to windows on MacOS.
  4. Get local IPv4 address of Windows.
  5. connect to smb://win-ipv4-address.

Troubleshooting

Couldn't connect to windows

Change firewall settings in Windows on remote address.

SMB-OuT

item.title: Setup Nginx reverse proxy for apache2 on Raspberry pi
item.description: About this post After creating my own nginx and apache configuration files for deploying local websites on raspberry pi, the learning curveâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
About this post

After creating my own nginx and apache configuration files for deploying local websites on raspberry pi, the learning curve isn't so steep as I thought it would be before. Anyway, it does feel great when you accomplish what you had expected for before.

If you prefer detailed tutorials about how to configure nginx, I recommond reading Nginx's official docs as there are a variety of configuration templates for different use cases. I wouldn't cover sytanx stuff in this post and you should learn it by reading the offical docs instead of reading a post that written for recording.

Why Nginx and Apache2

Nginx is a web server that does a good job on proxying and supports fastCGI for php rendering. Apache is a classic and old-school web server for serving static files.

Deploy and Reverse proxy

Here is my situation. I would like to proxy requests to /public/ on port 80 to a http file server listening on a port other than 80 e.g. port 3000, proxy requests to root url on port 80 to a php website dashboard-pi and proxy requests to /blog/ to my blog deployed with Apache2 on port 8080.

Install Nginx and Apache2

It doesn't matter that the raspberry pi has VRMv7 architecture as we could use sudo apt install nginx to auto-install suitable version. And so does to install Apache2, we could use sudo apt install apache2.

For mac, use brew install nginx httpd.

To start Nginx and Apache2, run:sudo systemctl start nginx and sudo systemctl start apache2.

Install php and php-fastCGI

To install php, run:sudo apt install php php-fpm.

Customize my configuration

The Nginx use nginx.conf as its configuration file under /etc/nginx/ on raspberry pi.

# go nginx 
cd /etc/nginx
vim nginx.conf

Here is the my configuration for nginx.conf:

user www-data;
worker_processes 1;
pid /run/nginx.pid;
include /etc/nginx/modules-enabled/*.conf;

events {
    worker_connections 256;
    # multi_accept on;
}

http {

    ##
    # Basic Settings
    ##

    sendfile on;
    tcp_nopush on;
    tcp_nodelay on;
    keepalive_timeout 65;
    types_hash_max_size 2048;
    # server_tokens off;

    # server_names_hash_bucket_size 64;
    # server_name_in_redirect off;

    include /etc/nginx/mime.types;
    default_type application/octet-stream;

    ##
    # SSL Settings
    ##

    ssl_protocols TLSv1 TLSv1.1 TLSv1.2; # Dropping SSLv3, ref: POODLE
    ssl_prefer_server_ciphers on;

    ##
    # Logging Settings
    ##

    access_log /var/log/nginx/access.log;
    error_log /var/log/nginx/error.log;

    ##
    # Gzip Settings
    ##

    gzip on;
    gzip_disable "msie6";

    gzip_vary on;
    gzip_proxied any;
    gzip_comp_level 6;
    gzip_buffers 16 8k;
    gzip_http_version 1.1;
    gzip_types text/plain text/css application/json application/javascript text/xml application/xml application/xml+rss text/javascript;

    ##
    # Virtual Host Configs
    ##

    include /etc/nginx/conf.d/*.conf;
    include /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/*;
}

Here is the reverse proxy configuration:

server {
    listen 80 default_server;
    listen [::]:80 default_server;

    root /var/www/pi-dashboard;

    # Add index.php to the list if you are using PHP
    index index.html index.htm index.nginx-debian.html index.php;

    server_name _;

    location / {
        index index.html index.htm index.nginx-debian.html index.php;
    }
    location /blog/ {
        proxy_pass http://192.168.50.136:8080;
        proxy_redirect off;
        proxy_read_timeout 1200;
        proxy_send_timeout 1200;
        proxy_connect_timeout 75;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
    }
    
    location /hfs/ {
        proxy_pass http://192.168.50.136:3000;
        proxy_redirect off;
        proxy_read_timeout 1200;
        proxy_send_timeout 1200;
        proxy_connect_timeout 75;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
    }

    # pass PHP scripts to FastCGI server
    location ~ \.php$ {
        include snippets/fastcgi-php.conf;
    
        # With php-fpm (or other unix sockets):
        fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php/php7.3-fpm.sock;
        fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
        # With php-cgi (or other tcp sockets):
        # fastcgi_pass 127.0.0.1:9000;
    }
}

item.title: Deploy DevDocs running locally on Linux as service
item.description: This is my first post about configuration stuff. In my opinion, configuring always consumes more time than coding. Another option forâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
This is my first post about configuration stuff. In my opinion, configuring always consumes more time than coding.

Another option for Windows/macOS

Dash is another possible option for mac users if you don't want to spend lots of time on configuring stuff. BTW, Dash is not FREE though you could download and use it for free ğŸ˜€.

Velocity is like Dash in Windows. It is also like Dash in the way that it's not free.

Install dependencies

You could follow the official instructions on DevDocs's github repo to deploy DevDocs on your local machine.

First, make sure you have installed ruby,curl and a JavaScript runtime supported by ExecJS (You could always choose Nodejs as your first option).

For the sake of saving keystrokes, I running all following commands as root.

ruby

# ruby-2.6.5 is required by app
# here I use rvm to manage different versions of rubies and it is like nvm for nodeJS

# 1. install gpg keys
# you need to check out https://rvm.io for latest gpg keys
# 2. install rvm
\curl -sSL https://get.rvm.io | bash -s stable
# 3. install ruby
rvm install 2.6.5  
# configuration stuff bala bala if you do not installed rvm as root
# for example, you need to add `source ~/.rvm/scripts/rvm` to your .bashrc

Then you could use ruby --version or rvm list to check its installation.

curl

If you are a Linux user, the system may has already installed curl e.g. Ubuntu. You could check it use which curl.

If not, please google how to install it with your system package manager.

Nodejs

Please go to nodejs website and choose a suitable binary/Installer for your platform.

Here I install Node binary files directly. 

mkdir -p node && tar -xvf node-v12.16.1-linux-armv7l.tar.xz -C node --strip-components 1
# install nodejs
cp -rvf node/* /usr/

Here is a reference if something goes wrong how-to-install-node-binary-distribution-files-on-linux

Running as a Linux service

follow official quick start

git clone https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/devdocs.git && cd devdocs
cd devdocs
gem install bundler
bundle install
bundle exec thor docs:download --default

If you do not want running it as a Linux service, it's done here.

Create new linux service with systemd

You could create a devdocs.service file under /etc/systemd/service/ or /lib/systemd/system/ provided by linux distribution.

Here is the unit configuration file devdocs.service. You should change following path according to your installation.

Use which to locate path to bundle and rackup. You should be careful that the ruby you get from which ruby doesn't include environment. Insead, you should use ruby under /path/to/rvm/gems/ruby-version/wrappers/.

Otherwise you may encounter ruby_executeable_hooks error. Here is the reference how-to-solve-usr-bin-env-ruby-executable-hooks-no-such-file-or-directory.

[Unit]
Description=devdocs in raspberry pi

[Service]
Type=simple
SyslogIdentifier=devdocs-pi
User=root
PIDFile=/home/pi/devdocs.pid
Environment=BUNDLE_GEMFILE=/home/pi/devdocs/Gemfile
ExecStart=/usr/local/rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/wrappers/ruby /usr/local/rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/bin/bundle exec /usr/local/rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/bin/rackup /home/pi/devdocs/config.ru --host 192.168.50.136 --port 9292
ExecReload=/usr/local/rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/wrappers/ruby /usr/local/rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/bin/bundle exec /usr/local/rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/bin/rackup /home/pi/devdocs/config.ru --host 192.168.50.136 --port 9292
ExecStop=/bin/kill -s QUIT $MAINPID
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

Fix some path error in files

At first I do not setup WorkingDirectory in unit configuration file so there are some files under devdocs/lib with relative path import that would cause issues. The solution I took was to hard-code the path in those files.

Use grep to filter files that may cause issues.

root:~/devdocs/lib $ grep -rnw "." -e "assets"

Systemctl and debug

Here we could run ruby application as a Linux service.

# reload systemd configuration files and unit files
systemctl daemon-reload
# start devdocs
systemctl enable devdocs
systemctl start devdocs
# debug
systemctl status devdocs
# or
journalctl -u devdocs

item.title: Improve blog performance with lighthouse
item.description: TL;DR Here is how I improve my blog's performance: Reduce image size (Compress JPEG image) Reduce font size (Replace truetype font .ttf withâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
TL;DR Here is how I improve my blog's performance:

  1. Reduce image size (Compress JPEG image)
  2. Reduce font size (Replace truetype font .ttf with Web Open Font Format font .woff or .woff2)
  3. Preload font file
  4. Use inline SVGs instead of loading them through font-awesome library

Reduce image size

At first, I used gatsby-image to lazy loading images like avatar but soon I found some issues then I had to remove it to use native image element. The original image I used for avatar is about 1.8 MB, which is a HUGE number in website. This led to the result that you have to wait for seconds to loading the image. When your network speed is worse, it could be longer.

To address this problem, I used an online image compression tool to reduce the size from 1.8 MB to only about 3 KB. That is epic.

Reduce font size

Just like compressing image, you could use similar way to get compressed font for website. The latest web font format is Woff2 and it offers a 30% average gain over Woff1.0. Then the font file decreased from around 200KB to 44KB.

Preload font

As Gatsby has already wrapped its webpack configuration, it would automatically minify the css & js bundle once we build the blog. However, for preloading font, according to the issue 14281 on the Github, we have to use a plugin called gatsby-plugin-preload-fonts.

// https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby/issues/13074
import RangaFont from '../../assets/fonts/ranga.woff2';
import RobotoFont from '../../assets/fonts/roboto.woff2';
import '../../styles/fonts.scss';
          <link
            rel="preload"
            as="font"
            href={RangaFont}
            type="font/woff2"
            crossOrigin="anonymous"
          />
          <link
            rel="preload"
            as="font"
            href={RobotoFont}
            type="font/woff2"
            crossOrigin="anonymous"
          />

Use inline SVGs

In this way, I do need to load third party library.

// before
import { FontAwesomeIcon } from '@fortawesome/react-fontawesome';
import { faTags } from '@fortawesome/free-solid-svg-icons';

<FontAwesomeIcon icon={faTags} size="sm" />
// after
      <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 480 512">
        <path d="M186.1 328.7c0 20.9-10.9 55.1-36.7 55.1s-36.7-34.2-36.7-55.1 10.9-55.1 36.7-55.1 36.7 34.2 36.7 55.1zM480 278.2c0 31.9-3.2 65.7-17.5 95-37.9 76.6-142.1 74.8-216.7 74.8-75.8 0-186.2 2.7-225.6-74.8-14.6-29-20.2-63.1-20.2-95 0-41.9 13.9-81.5 41.5-113.6-5.2-15.8-7.7-32.4-7.7-48.8 0-21.5 4.9-32.3 14.6-51.8 45.3 0 74.3 9 108.8 36 29-6.9 58.8-10 88.7-10 27 0 54.2 2.9 80.4 9.2 34-26.7 63-35.2 107.8-35.2 9.8 19.5 14.6 30.3 14.6 51.8 0 16.4-2.6 32.7-7.7 48.2 27.5 32.4 39 72.3 39 114.2zm-64.3 50.5c0-43.9-26.7-82.6-73.5-82.6-18.9 0-37 3.4-56 6-14.9 2.3-29.8 3.2-45.1 3.2-15.2 0-30.1-.9-45.1-3.2-18.7-2.6-37-6-56-6-46.8 0-73.5 38.7-73.5 82.6 0 87.8 80.4 101.3 150.4 101.3h48.2c70.3 0 150.6-13.4 150.6-101.3zm-82.6-55.1c-25.8 0-36.7 34.2-36.7 55.1s10.9 55.1 36.7 55.1 36.7-34.2 36.7-55.1-10.9-55.1-36.7-55.1z" />
      </svg>

Other techniques

Here are some things that I did not use but are also helpful for improving web performance:

  1. Splitting CSS
  • Load mobile css file in mobile only
  1. Using CDN to load static files like images
  2. Lazy loading images or videos

item.title: linked list cycle detection
item.description: update: "2020-01-15" BTW, This is the famous Floyd cycle detection algorithm. Problem To detect whether there is a loop in linked list, weâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
update: "2020-01-15"

BTW, This is the famous Floyd cycle detection algorithm.

Problem

To detect whether there is a loop in linked list, we could use two pointers approach.


type ListNode struct{
    val int
    next *ListNode
}

func detectLoop(head *ListNode)bool{
    slow, fast := head, head;
    for fast != nil && fats.next != nil{
        slow = slow.next;
        fast = fast.next.next;
        if slow == fast{
            // if there is a loop then tow pointers will meet eventually
           return true;
        }
    }
    return false;
}

The code above is simple and efficient. However, What if we want to know where dose the loop start at? We may could use tow pointers approach as before but the question is how we tweak the code.

By using two pointers we know one of them takes 1 step each time and another takes 2 steps. If there is a loop, they will meet each other soon or later. Let's assume the first meet occurs at step XXX. Does it help us solve this problem? Yes, you are almost there but you have to get the help from math.

Suppose the length of loop is MMM.

2â‹…Xâˆ’X=X=kâ‹…M,kâˆˆN2\cdot{X} - X = X = k\cdot{M}, k\in{N}2â‹…Xâˆ’X=X=kâ‹…M,kâˆˆN

You may wonder how to prove the equation. Here it comes, with the help of following graphs.

X=2â‹…Xâˆ’X={MifÂ M>1Xâ‹…1ifÂ M=1X = 2\cdot{X} - X = \begin{cases} M &\text{if M}>{1} \\ X\cdot{1} &\text{if M}=1 \end{cases}X=2â‹…Xâˆ’X={MXâ‹…1â€‹ifÂ M>1ifÂ M=1â€‹

Suppose the distance between the list head and the loop start is YYY and the offset of meeting node in the loop is SSS. From the above graph we could also get the equation X=Y+Sâ‡”Y=Xâˆ’S=kâ‹…Mâˆ’S=(kâˆ’1)â‹…M+Mâˆ’SX = Y + S \Leftrightarrow Y = X - S = k\cdot{M} - S = (k-1)\cdot{M} + M - SX=Y+Sâ‡”Y=Xâˆ’S=kâ‹…Mâˆ’S=(kâˆ’1)â‹…M+Mâˆ’S.

To make it simple, set k=1k=1k=1, we get Y=Mâˆ’SY = M - SY=Mâˆ’S. Do you find what Mâˆ’SM - SMâˆ’S represents in the graph?

Now it's obvious that we could use another pair of points that one starts from the list head and another one starts from the first meeting node. Both of them take 1 step each time so when they first meet each other we find the start of the loop.

The code is also straightforward.

// return nil if not found
func getLoopIndex(head *ListNode)*ListNode{
if head == nil{
    return nil;
}
slow, fast := head, head;
for fast != nil && fast.next!=nil{
    slow = slow.next;
    fast = fast.next.next;
    if slow == fast{
        break;
    }
}
if slow == fast{
    p1,p2 := head,slow;
    for p1 != p2{
        p1 = p1.next;
        p2 = p2.next;
    }
    return p1;
}
return nil;
}

item.title: accelerate blog deployment
item.description: To be honest, I have been using another repo to deploy static files from gatsby build. The process is tedious that each time I have toâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
To be honest, I have been using another repo to deploy static files from gatsby build. The process is tedious that each time I have to update the blog manually (open the terminal and enter some git commands to push the latest update to the remote repo).

At the beginning, I didn't consider it as an issue because I focused on development at that time. However, the more times I publish my blog, the more inconvenient I feel from this.

For the sake of simplicity, I want to write some scripts to accelerate the deployment.

Bash Script

This is the easiest way to achieve my requirement with both the simplicity and efficiency.

Just like another script I wrote for the X86 instruction book deployed with TravisCI, the script is composed of three steps.

  1. Set up constants
  2. Execute commands
  3. Remove temporary files or directories
#!/bin/bash
# simple deployment script
REPO="git@github.com:tizee/tizee.github.io.git"
CUR=`pwd`

# 1. creat a temporary directory
mkdir -v -p ./_BlogBuild/temp_repo
cp -v public/* ./_BlogBuild/temp_repo/

# 2. create a new git repo
cd ./_BlogBuild/temp_repo && git init

# 3. push --force to remote repo origin master branch
git add -A && git commit -m "auto deploy" git push --force -u $REPO master

# 4. remove directory
cd $CUR && rm -r -f ../_BlogBuild/temp_repo

# 5. done!!

Cross-platform solution: Nodejs script

However, right now the OS I'm using is Windows 10 which is tedious to run above bash script through WSL. Hence, I decide to write a JavaScript version of it, which use Node.js built-in libraries that could enable cross-platform feature.

const fs = require('fs');
const cp = require('child_process');
const path = require('path');

const CUR = process.cwd();
const TEMP_DIR = path.join(CUR, 'temp');
const SRC = path.join(CUR, 'public');
const REPO = 'git@github.com:tizee/tizee.github.io.git';
console.log(`CUR: ${CUR}`);
console.log(`TEMP_DIR: ${TEMP_DIR}`);
console.log(`SRC: ${SRC}`);
console.log(`REPO: ${REPO}`);

// copying files recursively
const copyFileRecursive = (src, dest) => {
  const isExist = fs.existsSync(src);
  if (!isExist) {
    return;
  }
  const isDirectory = fs.lstatSync(src).isDirectory();
  if (isDirectory) {
    fs.mkdirSync(dest);
    fs.readdirSync(src).forEach((file) => {
      let curSrc = path.join(src, file);
      if (fs.lstatSync(curSrc).isDirectory()) {
        copyFileRecursive(curSrc, path.join(dest, file));
      } else {
        fs.copyFileSync(curSrc, path.join(dest, file), fs.constants.COPYFILE_EXCL);
      }
    });
  } else {
    fs.copyFileSync(src, dest, fs.constants.COPYFILE_EXCL);
  }
};

copyFileRecursive(SRC, TEMP_DIR);
console.log('â™ª copy files done!');

// git init && git add all
const shell = cp.execSync;
const options = { cwd: TEMP_DIR };
const gitShell = (command) => {
  shell(command, options);
};
gitShell(`git init`);
console.log('â™ª git init done!');
gitShell(`git add -A`);
console.log('â™ª git add done!');
gitShell(`git commit -m "updated by auto deployment script"`);
console.log('â™ª git commit done!');
gitShell(`git push -f -u ${REPO} master`);
console.log('â™ª git push done!');

// remove temporary directory
shell(`rm -r -f ${TEMP_DIR}`);
// done!
console.log(`â™ª remove ${TEMP_DIR} done!`);

item.title: Rewrite blog UI with CSS in JS
item.description: Recently I read Talia Marcassaâ€™s post Styled Components: To Use or Not to use ? and I was thinking rewrite my all UI components usingâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
Recently I read Talia Marcassaâ€™s post Styled Components: To Use or Not to use ? and I was thinking rewrite my all UI components using styled-components to make it more structural.

Here are her top highlight words: Furthermore, when you have components that rely on JavaScript for their style, Styled Components gives control of those states back to CSS instead of using a multitude of conditional class names.

That precisely describe what my old codebase looks like. I used OBEM as my css naming style so there are lots of class names with slashes in separated SCSS files.

She pointed out there are four reasons why people like styled-components.

  1. It makes components less bulky For example, instead of using objects and React event handlers to setup a hover state, use styled-component enable us to use CSS to handle UI states.
  2. The ThemeProvider Her team used the ThemeProvider to build a configuration page which allows a user to customize certain stylistic elements like colors.
  3. The CSS function BTW, I also used styled-componentsâ€™ css function in my blogâ€™s UI components to conditionally render css, which like she said, we no longer had to render conditional class names based on props. In her opinion, this reduces clutter in components as well as maintains a separation of concerns between CSS and JavaScript.
  4. Testing Her team implemented the Jest Styled-Components library for testing in Jest. As she mentioned in her post, It makes testing styled components painless by creating consistent class names and allowing developers to assert specific CSS rules that might be important to the integrity of your app.

She also said there are drawbacks about styled components.

For example, there are certain style rules that her team found hard to apply to styled components e.g. rules that set the placement of an element on a page like margin or display properties.

In conclusion, use styled components will reduce the complexity of your codebase.

It's easy for me to rewrite my blog UI components with the help of styled-components function and JavaScript's template literals.

However, there are a few problems I need to address in the header component. The scroll animation was controlled by its CSS class names, which is not recommended in styled-components. I separated the whole header component to several sub-components like menu components that include desktop version and mobile version, modal component which only functions when mobile menu is open and navbar hamburger component.

This made my code more structural and I could update these sub-components independently in the future.

I also consider adding more features like theme to my blog, which inspired by the Alligator and mouseover dropdown menu to the navbar menu, which is commonly used in modern website.

item.title: My first interview
item.description: There are no details about interview questions in this post. Here I just wanted to focus on how I handle the job rejection. Several days agoâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
There are no details about interview questions in this post. Here I just wanted to focus on how I handle the job rejection.

Several days ago I attended my first internship interview. My feeling about the interview wasn't bad in spite of mistakes I had made. However, I didn't pass the interview, which didn't surprise me.

There are probably many reasons for this depressing result, which are omitted in the interview result e-mail. Therefore I need to figure it out myself.

To be honest, after I finished my interview, sitting on the seat of subway and listening to the music playing in the headphone, I was dreaming I passed the interview and got my first internship job. The interviewer made me feel good about myself, and as TechLead said in his video Interview Rejection - How to handle failure (in tech): Don't count on that!

Deep in my heart, I knew I may fail the interview but there were also chance that I could pass it so I grasped the hope. When the result didn't reach your high expectation, you would most likely feel depressed. It is like gambling that you have chance to win and you believe it but you lose the game in the end.

The moment I knew the result, I started doubt my talents and ability. I asked myself that does it make me like a loser? The answer was absolutely not. From the view of statistics, it's common for a senior college student to get rejected when applying his first internship job.

Nobody likes failure. The only thing I could do was learn from it. Katharine wrote these in her post Rejection and the Job Search, which helped me understand job rejection:

Just know that itâ€™s going to happen, and generally, itâ€™s not personal, even though it feels that way. I have hired a lot of coaches over the years and there are often 50 candidates for one position. That means 49 rejections. You are definitely not alone, and you are not in the minority if you are rejected. Learn what you can, change what you should, and then let it go and move on to the next opportunity. You are not defined by your rejection.

She provides several tips:

  1. Don't ask feedback if you don't want to know
  2. Take advantage of what you are learning in the search process
  3. Prepare yourself psychologically for rejection.

She answered the question why I didn't get many interviews as I expect:

If you arenâ€™t getting interviews, it may be your resume, cover letter, or application. Ask an outside neutral party to review your materials to make sure youâ€™re not missing anything. Are you targeting your resume to the specific position or are you sending a generic resume to all openings? Do your research on the employer and the position, and make sure your resume focuses on what each employer needs.

I may get more job rejection in the future, but all I need is one. After many failures, we only need a happy success in the end.

item.title: Reservoir Algorithm
item.description: This is an interesting problem I came across at Leetcode . The question Question: get K random values from N values Straight-forwardâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
This is an interesting problem I came across at Leetcode.

The question

Question: get K random values from N values

Straight-forward solution

The straight-forward way to retrieve K random values from a list is that use the array to store all possible values and use pseudo-random generator API like rand() in C++ or Math.random() in JavaScript to get K random indexes.

However, when the list length N goes extremely large or couldn't be known beforehand such as the container is a linked list, this simple method fails. To be more precise, once N is large, we couldn't load all data into the memory to retrieve a random value.

var Solution = function(head) {
   this.arr = [];
   let cur = head;
    while(cur){
        this.arr.push(cur.val);
        cur = cur.next;
    }
};

/**
 * Returns a random node's value.
 * @return {number}
 */
Solution.prototype.getRandom = function() {
   return this.arr[Math.floor(Math.random()*this.arr.length)];
};

Reservoir sampling algorithm

Now that we couldn't load all random or couldn't know the size of list, we just need make sure the result satisfy the statistical theory that all values have the same probability of KN\frac{K}{N}NKâ€‹.

Algorithm

  1. Choose first K values and put them into the reservoir.
  2. For K+1K+1K+1 th (1-indexed) value, pick it with a probability of KK+1\frac{K}{K+1}K+1Kâ€‹ , then use it to randomly replace a number in the reservoir.
  3. For K+iK+iK+i th value, pick it with a probability of KK+i\frac{K}{K+i}K+iKâ€‹, then use it to randomly replace a number in the reservoir.
  4. repeat until K+iK+iK+i reach N
class Solution {
private:
    ListNode* head;
public:
    /** @param head The linked list's head.
        Note that the head is guaranteed to be not null, so it contains at least one node. */
    Solution(ListNode* head) {
        this->head = head;
    }

    /** Returns a random node's value. */
    int getRandom() {
        int ans = this->head->val;
        ListNode* candidate = this->head->next;
        int cnt = 2;
        while(candidate){
           int j = rand()%cnt;
            if(j==0){
                ans = candidate->val;
            }
            cnt++;
            candidate=candidate->next;
        }
        return ans;
        }
};

Simple proof

For a number XXX in the reservoir, the probability that it continues staying in the reservoir is:

P(XinÂ currentÂ reservoir)=P(XinÂ previousÂ reservoir)â‹…P(XnotÂ replacedÂ byÂ K+i)=P(XinÂ previousÂ reservoir)â‹…(1âˆ’P(XreplacedÂ byÂ K+i))=KK+iâˆ’1â‹…(1âˆ’KK+iâ‹…1K)=KK+iâˆ’1â‹…K+iâˆ’1K+i=KK+i\begin {aligned} P(X_{\text{in current reservoir}}) &= P(X_{\text{in previous reservoir}}) \cdot P(X_{\text{not replaced by K+i}}) \\ &= P(X_{\text{in previous reservoir}}) \cdot (1 - P(X_{\text{replaced by K+i}})) \\ &= \frac{K}{K+i-1} \cdot (1 - \frac{K}{K+i} \cdot \frac{1}{K}) \\ &= \frac{K}{K+i-1} \cdot \frac{K+i-1}{K+i} \\ &= \frac{K}{K+i} \end {aligned}P(XinÂ currentÂ reservoirâ€‹)â€‹=P(XinÂ previousÂ reservoirâ€‹)â‹…P(XnotÂ replacedÂ byÂ K+iâ€‹)=P(XinÂ previousÂ reservoirâ€‹)â‹…(1âˆ’P(XreplacedÂ byÂ K+iâ€‹))=K+iâˆ’1Kâ€‹â‹…(1âˆ’K+iKâ€‹â‹…K1â€‹)=K+iâˆ’1Kâ€‹â‹…K+iK+iâˆ’1â€‹=K+iKâ€‹â€‹

So when K+i=NK+i = NK+i=N, the probability of each number staying in the reservoir is KN\frac{K}{N}NKâ€‹.

Q.E.D

Reference

  • leetcode linked-list-random-node
  • wiki Reservoir Sampling

item.title: It is time to cross origin
item.description: There are several ways to cross origin using vanilla JavaScript. If you are familiar with front-end cross origin techniques, you could skipâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
There are several ways to cross origin using vanilla JavaScript. If you are familiar with front-end cross origin techniques, you could skip this post.

What is an origin

If you are familiar with computer networking, you could skip this paragraph.

const url = "https://api.foobar.com/data/users/foo/";
const protocol = "https";
const subDomain = "api";
const domain = "foobra";
const topLevelDomain = "com";
const URI = "/data/users/foo";

For example, https://api.foobar.com and https://www.foobar.com are two different subdomain under the same domain https://*.foobar.com.

CORS

At most time, the pages users access are under https://www.foobar.com. The XMLHttpRequest could only access the resources under the same domain by default.

The Cross-Origin Resource Sharing defines how browser communicates with the server when it has to request resource on another domain. The browser has to add an additional http header parameter Origin. And the server would return response message with Access-Control-Allow-Origin header.

XMLHttpRequest

The modern web browsers (except IE8) all support CORS by default. To use CORS, you just need to pass the absolute URLs in the XMLHttpRequest objects.

XMLHttpRequest can only be used to request URL with the same protocol that under the same domain(Or use absolute URLs to enable CORS)

let xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
xhr.onreadyStatechange = function(){
  if(xhr.readyState=== 4){
    if((xhr.status>=200 && xhr.status<300) || xhr.status=== 304){
      console.log(xhr.responseText);
    }else{
      console.log(xhr.status);
    }
  }
};
xhr.open("get","https://api.foobar.com/users/foo",true);
xhr.send(null);

Img Ping

This is a one-way cross-origin communication method.

let img = new Image();
img.onload = img.onerror = function(){
  // callback when finished
  console.log("done");
}
img.src= "https://api.foorbar.com/users/foor";

We could set the same handler for event onload and onerror so once the request is completed we could run some code.

The drawback is obvious that it only supports Http get method and we couldn't access the response text.

JSONP

JSON with padding wraps JSON data in a callback function. The JSONP consists of JSON and a callback function.

function handleCallback(response){
  console.log(response);
}

let script = document.createElement("script");
script.src= "https://api.foobar.com/user/foo?callback=handleCallback";
document.body.insertBefore(script,document.body.firstChild);

Using JSONP, we could access the response text. It also supports two-way communication between the browser and the server.

However, when using JSONP, we should make sure the callback function code and the response from other domain is secure.

Another shortcoming is that it's hard to determine whether a request is failed or not.

Comet

Comet is a server-side technique that pushing data to the browser from the server for frequently updated data like living sports matches' scores.

Sever-sent Events(SSE)
let source =new EventSource("https://api.foorbar.com/users");
source.onmessage = function(e){
  let data = e.data;
  // handle data
}
source.close();

Web Sockets

To use web sockets in front-end, you need to make sure your server support it. The protocol that web socket uses starts with ws:// or wss:// as corresponding to https://.

It enables full duplex between the browser and the server and the data packet is rather small compared with Http's.

// must pass absoulte URLs
let socket = new WebSocket('ws://www.foobar.com/users');
socket.onmessage = function(e){
  let data = e.data;
  // handle data
}
socket.send("hello");
let data = {
  name: 'foobar'
};
socket.send(JSON.stringify(data));
socket.close();

item.title: Http to Https
item.description: Nowadays almost all websites that have Https URLs enabled are secured with a certificate so users could access these trusted websites in aâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
Nowadays almost all websites that have Https URLs enabled are secured with a certificate so users could access these trusted websites in a private connection. Nevertheless, websites with Http identifier URLs are vulnerable to man-in-middle or eavesdropping attacks.

Http: a vulnerable protocol

Http protocol does not defined how to make its messages secured. Therefore, when the client communicates with the server on a Http connection, the messages could be faked or eavesdropped by a third person.

Https: Http over TLS/Http over SSL

Https was formally specified in RFC 2818 in 2000.

The default port of Http/TLS is 443, which is different from http's port number 80.

Conceptually, HTTP/TLS is very simple. Simply use HTTP over TLS precisely as you would use HTTP over TCP.

To enable Https protocol for a website, the website administrator must create a public key certificate for the website server (the actual web server that the website domain pointed to).

To understand how https works, we must understand following several words.

CA: Certificate Authority

The web administrator must create a public key certificate from trusted certificate authority. In other words, website owners should sign up their websites on one of these trusted certificate authorities so they could acquire SSL/TLS certificates from the authority.

The authority certificates that the certificate holder is trusted and is the operator of the web server. Browsers could verify these certificates signed by trusted authorities.

For instance, Let's encrypt provides free and automated service that generates SSL/TLS certificates to websites.

SSL/TLS

The SSL is now deprecated and TLS is commonly used in Https encryption. You may wonder what do the SSL and TLS stand for.

SSL is the shorthand of Secure Socket Layer and TLS is the shorthand for Transport Layer Security. Both of SSL and TLS are cryptographic protocols that provide communication security over the transport layer.

It's hard to locate which layer SSL/TLS using OSI model or TCP/IP model according to an answer on stack-exchange.

The TLS layer wraps the application layer traffic in encryption during transport. You could imagine the TLS stands between the Application layer and the Transport layer.

Reference

RFC 2818

wiki Https

wiki TLS
